newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhs may sell grain to Turkmenistan, Georgia.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhs may sell grain to Turkmenistan, Georgia.

text.p: Kazakhstan may sell its Central Asian neighbour Turkmenistan 100,000 tonnes of wheat from its 1996 crop, a senior agriculture official said on Tuesday.
Deputy Agriculture Minister Anatoly Romanov said Turkmenistan was ready to pay at least $165 a tonne.
He also said the former Soviet republic of Georgia was seeking 20,000 tonnes of Kazakh grain.

Almaty has forecast a 1996 net grain harvest of 13-14 million tonnes, while independent sources have said output would be only 11 million tonnes. Other analysts have said that actual production is under-reported by several million tonnes.
Kazakhstan has said it hopes to export at least five to six million tonnes from this year's crop, and has also cited Russia and Tajikistan as likely buyers.
